trans-unit.source: Walkthrough: export telemetry to SQL Database from Application Insights
trans-unit.target: Walkthrough: export telemetry to SQL Database from Application Insights

trans-unit.source: Code your own analysis of telemetry in Application Insights by using the continuous export feature.
trans-unit.target: Code your own analysis of telemetry in Application Insights by using the continuous export feature.

trans-unit.source: This article shows how to move your telemetry data from <linkText>Visual Studio Application Insights[start]</linkText><title></title> into an Azure SQL database by using <linkText>Continuous Export[export]</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>Azure Stream Analytics</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: This article shows how to move your telemetry data from <linkText>Visual Studio Application Insights[start]</linkText><title></title> into an Azure SQL database by using <linkText>Continuous Export[export]</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>Azure Stream Analytics</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Continuous export moves your telemetry data into Azure Storage in JSON format.
trans-unit.target: Continuous export moves your telemetry data into Azure Storage in JSON format.

trans-unit.source: We'll parse the JSON objects using Azure Stream Analytics and create rows in a database table.
trans-unit.target: We'll parse the JSON objects using Azure Stream Analytics and create rows in a database table.

trans-unit.source: (More generally, Continuous Export is the way to do your own analysis of the telemetry your apps send to Application Insights.
trans-unit.target: (More generally, Continuous Export is the way to do your own analysis of the telemetry your apps send to Application Insights.

trans-unit.source: You could adapt this code sample to do other things with the exported telemetry, such as aggregation of data and publishing the data to the PowerBI visualization suite.)
trans-unit.target: You could adapt this code sample to do other things with the exported telemetry, such as aggregation of data and publishing the data to the PowerBI visualization suite.)

trans-unit.source: We'll start with the assumption that you already have the app you want to monitor.
trans-unit.target: We'll start with the assumption that you already have the app you want to monitor.

trans-unit.source: In this example, we will be using the page view data, but the same pattern can easily be extended to other data types such as custom events and exceptions.
trans-unit.target: In this example, we will be using the page view data, but the same pattern can easily be extended to other data types such as custom events and exceptions.

trans-unit.source: To monitor your application, you <linkText>add an Application Insights SDK[start]</linkText><title></title> to your application.
trans-unit.target: To monitor your application, you <linkText>add an Application Insights SDK[start]</linkText><title></title> to your application.

trans-unit.source: There are different SDKs and helper tools for different platforms, IDEs and languages.
trans-unit.target: There are different SDKs and helper tools for different platforms, IDEs and languages.

trans-unit.source: You can monitor web pages, Java or ASP.NET web servers, and mobile devices of several kinds.
trans-unit.target: You can monitor web pages, Java or ASP.NET web servers, and mobile devices of several kinds.

trans-unit.source: All the SDKs send telemetry to the <linkText>Application Insights portal[portal]</linkText><title></title>, where you can use our powerful analysis and diagnostic tools, and export the data to storage.
trans-unit.target: All the SDKs send telemetry to the <linkText>Application Insights portal[portal]</linkText><title></title>, where you can use our powerful analysis and diagnostic tools, and export the data to storage.

trans-unit.source: To get started:
trans-unit.target: To get started:

trans-unit.source: Get an <linkText>account in Microsoft Azure</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Get an <linkText>account in Microsoft Azure</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: In the <linkText>Azure portal[portal]</linkText><title></title>, add a new Application Insights resource for your app:
trans-unit.target: In the <linkText>Azure portal[portal]</linkText><title></title>, add a new Application Insights resource for your app:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Choose New, Developer Services, Application Insights, and choose the type of application</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Choose New, Developer Services, Application Insights, and choose the type of application</linkText>

trans-unit.source: (Your app type and subscription might be different.)
trans-unit.target: (Your app type and subscription might be different.)

trans-unit.source: Open Quick Start to find how to set up the SDK for your app type.
trans-unit.target: Open Quick Start to find how to set up the SDK for your app type.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Choose Quick Start and follow instructions</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Choose Quick Start and follow instructions</linkText>

trans-unit.source: If your app type isn't listed, take a look at the <linkText>Getting Started[start]</linkText><title></title> page.
trans-unit.target: If your app type isn't listed, take a look at the <linkText>Getting Started[start]</linkText><title></title> page.

trans-unit.source: In this example, we're monitoring a web app, so we can use the Azure tools in Visual Studio to install the SDK.
trans-unit.target: In this example, we're monitoring a web app, so we can use the Azure tools in Visual Studio to install the SDK.

trans-unit.source: Tell it the name of your Application Insights resource:
trans-unit.target: Tell it the name of your Application Insights resource:

trans-unit.source: ![In Visual Studio Solution Explorer, right-click your project and choose Add Application Insights.
trans-unit.target: ![In Visual Studio Solution Explorer, right-click your project and choose Add Application Insights.

trans-unit.source: At Send telemetry to, choose to create a new resource, or use an existing one.](./media/app-insights-code-sample-export-sql-stream-analytics/appinsights-d012-addbrown.png)
trans-unit.target: At Send telemetry to, choose to create a new resource, or use an existing one.](./media/app-insights-code-sample-export-sql-stream-analytics/appinsights-d012-addbrown.png)

trans-unit.source: Publish your app, and watch telemetry data appearing in your Application Insights resource.
trans-unit.target: Publish your app, and watch telemetry data appearing in your Application Insights resource.

trans-unit.source: Continuous export always outputs data to an Azure Storage account, so you need to create the storage first.
trans-unit.target: Continuous export always outputs data to an Azure Storage account, so you need to create the storage first.

trans-unit.source: Create a storage account in your subscription in the <linkText>Azure portal[portal]</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Create a storage account in your subscription in the <linkText>Azure portal[portal]</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>In Azure portal, choose New, Data, Storage</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>In Azure portal, choose New, Data, Storage</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Create a container
trans-unit.target: Create a container

trans-unit.source: <linkText>In the new storage, select Containers and then Add</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>In the new storage, select Containers and then Add</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Copy the storage access key
trans-unit.target: Copy the storage access key

trans-unit.source: You'll need it soon to set up the input to the stream analytics service.
trans-unit.target: You'll need it soon to set up the input to the stream analytics service.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>In the storage, open Settings, Keys, and take a copy of the Primary Access Key</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>In the storage, open Settings, Keys, and take a copy of the Primary Access Key</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the Azure portal, browse to the Application Insights resource you created for your application.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure portal, browse to the Application Insights resource you created for your application.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Choose Browse, Application Insights, your application</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Choose Browse, Application Insights, your application</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Create a continuous export.
trans-unit.target: Create a continuous export.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Choose Settings, Continuous Export, Add</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Choose Settings, Continuous Export, Add</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Select the storage account you created earlier:
trans-unit.target: Select the storage account you created earlier:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Set the export destination</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Set the export destination</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Set the event types you want to see:
trans-unit.target: Set the event types you want to see:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Choose event types</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Choose event types</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Let some data accumulate.
trans-unit.target: Let some data accumulate.

trans-unit.source: Sit back and let people use your application for a while.
trans-unit.target: Sit back and let people use your application for a while.

trans-unit.source: Telemetry will come in and you'll see statistical charts in <linkText>metric explorer</linkText><title></title> and individual events in <linkText>diagnostic search</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Telemetry will come in and you'll see statistical charts in <linkText>metric explorer</linkText><title></title> and individual events in <linkText>diagnostic search</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: And also, the data will export to your storage.
trans-unit.target: And also, the data will export to your storage.

trans-unit.source: Inspect the exported data.
trans-unit.target: Inspect the exported data.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, choose View / Cloud Explorer, and open Azure / Storage.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, choose View / Cloud Explorer, and open Azure / Storage.

trans-unit.source: (If you don't have this menu option, you need to install the Azure SDK: Open the New Project dialog and open Visual C# / Cloud / Get Microsoft Azure SDK for .NET.)
trans-unit.target: (If you don't have this menu option, you need to install the Azure SDK: Open the New Project dialog and open Visual C# / Cloud / Get Microsoft Azure SDK for .NET.)

trans-unit.source: <linkText>In Visual Studio, open Server Browser, Azure, Storage</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>In Visual Studio, open Server Browser, Azure, Storage</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Make a note of the common part of the path name, which is derived from the application name and instrumentation key.
trans-unit.target: Make a note of the common part of the path name, which is derived from the application name and instrumentation key.

trans-unit.source: The events are written to blob files in JSON format.
trans-unit.target: The events are written to blob files in JSON format.

trans-unit.source: Each file may contain one or more events.
trans-unit.target: Each file may contain one or more events.

trans-unit.source: So we'd like to read the event data and filter out the fields we want.
trans-unit.target: So we'd like to read the event data and filter out the fields we want.

trans-unit.source: There are all kinds of things we could do with the data, but our plan today is to use Stream Analytics to move the data to a SQL database.
trans-unit.target: There are all kinds of things we could do with the data, but our plan today is to use Stream Analytics to move the data to a SQL database.

trans-unit.source: That will make it easy to run lots of interesting queries.
trans-unit.target: That will make it easy to run lots of interesting queries.

trans-unit.source: Once again starting from your subscription in <linkText>Azure portal[portal]</linkText><title></title>, create the database (and a new server, unless you've already got one) to which you'll write the data.
trans-unit.target: Once again starting from your subscription in <linkText>Azure portal[portal]</linkText><title></title>, create the database (and a new server, unless you've already got one) to which you'll write the data.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>New, Data, SQL</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>New, Data, SQL</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Make sure that the database server allows access to Azure services:
trans-unit.target: Make sure that the database server allows access to Azure services:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Browse, Servers, your server, Settings, Firewall, Allow Access to Azure</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Browse, Servers, your server, Settings, Firewall, Allow Access to Azure</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Connect to the database created in the previous section with your preferred management tool.
trans-unit.target: Connect to the database created in the previous section with your preferred management tool.

trans-unit.source: In this walkthrough, we will be using <linkText>SQL Server Management Tools</linkText><title></title> (SSMS).
trans-unit.target: In this walkthrough, we will be using <linkText>SQL Server Management Tools</linkText><title></title> (SSMS).

trans-unit.source: Create a new query, and execute the following T-SQL:
trans-unit.target: Create a new query, and execute the following T-SQL:

trans-unit.source: In this sample, we are using data from page views.
trans-unit.target: In this sample, we are using data from page views.

trans-unit.source: To see the other data available, inspect your JSON output, and see the <linkText>export data model</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To see the other data available, inspect your JSON output, and see the <linkText>export data model</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: From the <linkText>Classic Azure Portal</linkText><title></title>, select the Azure Stream Analytics service, and create a new Stream Analytics job:
trans-unit.target: From the <linkText>Classic Azure Portal</linkText><title></title>, select the Azure Stream Analytics service, and create a new Stream Analytics job:

trans-unit.source: When the new job is created, expand its details:
trans-unit.target: When the new job is created, expand its details:

trans-unit.source: Set it to take input from your Continuous Export blob:
trans-unit.target: Set it to take input from your Continuous Export blob:

trans-unit.source: Now you'll need the Primary Access Key from your Storage Account, which you noted earlier.
trans-unit.target: Now you'll need the Primary Access Key from your Storage Account, which you noted earlier.

trans-unit.source: Set this as the Storage Account Key.
trans-unit.target: Set this as the Storage Account Key.

trans-unit.source: Be sure to set the Date Format to YYYY-MM-DD (with dashes).
trans-unit.target: Be sure to set the Date Format to YYYY-MM-DD (with dashes).

trans-unit.source: The Path Prefix Pattern specifies how Stream Analytics finds the input files in the storage.
trans-unit.target: The Path Prefix Pattern specifies how Stream Analytics finds the input files in the storage.

trans-unit.source: You need to set it to correspond to how Continuous Export stores the data.
trans-unit.target: You need to set it to correspond to how Continuous Export stores the data.

trans-unit.source: Set it like this:
trans-unit.target: Set it like this:

trans-unit.source: In this example:
trans-unit.target: In this example:

trans-unit.source: webapplication27 is the name of the Application Insights resource, all in lower case.
trans-unit.target: webapplication27 is the name of the Application Insights resource, all in lower case.

trans-unit.source: 1234... is the instrumentation key of the Application Insights resource with dashes removed.
trans-unit.target: 1234... is the instrumentation key of the Application Insights resource with dashes removed.

trans-unit.source: PageViews is the type of data we want to analyze.
trans-unit.target: PageViews is the type of data we want to analyze.

trans-unit.source: The available types depend on the filter you set in Continuous Export.
trans-unit.target: The available types depend on the filter you set in Continuous Export.

trans-unit.source: Examine the exported data to see the other available types, and see the <linkText>export data model</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Examine the exported data to see the other available types, and see the <linkText>export data model</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: /{date}/{time} is a pattern written literally.
trans-unit.target: /{date}/{time} is a pattern written literally.

trans-unit.source: To get the name and iKey of your Application Insights resource, open Essentials on its overview page, or open Settings.
trans-unit.target: To get the name and iKey of your Application Insights resource, open Essentials on its overview page, or open Settings.

trans-unit.source: Confirm the serialization format:
trans-unit.target: Confirm the serialization format:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Confirm and close wizard</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Confirm and close wizard</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Close the wizard and wait for the setup to complete.
trans-unit.target: Close the wizard and wait for the setup to complete.

trans-unit.source: Open the query section:
trans-unit.target: Open the query section:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>In stream analytics, select Query</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>In stream analytics, select Query</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Replace the default query with:
trans-unit.target: Replace the default query with:

trans-unit.source: Notice that the first few properties are specific to page view data.
trans-unit.target: Notice that the first few properties are specific to page view data.

trans-unit.source: Exports of other telemetry types will have different properties.
trans-unit.target: Exports of other telemetry types will have different properties.

trans-unit.source: See the <linkText>detailed data model reference for the property types and values.</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: See the <linkText>detailed data model reference for the property types and values.</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Select SQL as the output.
trans-unit.target: Select SQL as the output.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>In stream analytics, select Outputs</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>In stream analytics, select Outputs</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Specify the SQL database.
trans-unit.target: Specify the SQL database.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Fill in the details of your database</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Fill in the details of your database</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Close the wizard and wait for a notification that the output has been set up.
trans-unit.target: Close the wizard and wait for a notification that the output has been set up.

trans-unit.source: Start the job from the action bar:
trans-unit.target: Start the job from the action bar:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>In stream analytics, click Start</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>In stream analytics, click Start</linkText>

trans-unit.source: You can choose whether to start processing the data starting from now, or to start with earlier data.
trans-unit.target: You can choose whether to start processing the data starting from now, or to start with earlier data.

trans-unit.source: The latter is useful if you have had Continuous Export already running for a while.
trans-unit.target: The latter is useful if you have had Continuous Export already running for a while.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>In stream analytics, click Start</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>In stream analytics, click Start</linkText>

trans-unit.source: After a few minutes, go back to SQL Server Management Tools and watch the data flowing in.
trans-unit.target: After a few minutes, go back to SQL Server Management Tools and watch the data flowing in.

trans-unit.source: For example, use a query like this:
trans-unit.target: For example, use a query like this:

trans-unit.target: <linkText>Export to SQL using a worker role</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.target: <linkText>Detailed data model reference for the property types and values.</linkText><title></title>
